Description:
Miller illustrates the scene of Prince Charles Edward fleeing after his failed insurrection. As Prince Regent of the exiled house of Stuart, he tried to regain the British throne by uniting Highland clansman and invading England. After his final defeat in 1746, he was chased across Scotland for several months before ultimately escaping to France.

This scene depicts one of his evasions: Flora MacDonald disguises him as an Irish spinning maid named Betty Burke.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: A Baltimore Watchman: An Exhibition of Drawings by Alfred Jacob Miller
Exhibitions.Textblock: A Baltimore Watchman: An Exhibition of Drawings by Alfred Jacob Miller. Government House, Annapolis. 1996.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Alfred Jacob Miller: Maryland and the West
Exhibitions.Textblock: Alfred Jacob Miller: Maryland and the West. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore; Washington College, Chestertown; Frostburg State University, Frostburg; Jewish Community Center of Greater Washington, Rockville. 1988.

Inscriptions: [Label] Beneath: Prince Charles Edward (disguised as a Lady's maid to Flora McDonald), escaping to Island of Sky, in an open boat. (Appendix to Boswell's Johnson)
Medium: black pen and wash on blue-gray paper
Provenance: Alfred Jacob Miller, Jr.; Norton Asner, Baltimore, 1959 [mode of acquisition unknown]; The Lisanelly Foundation [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; Walters Art Museum, June 11, 1968, by gift.
Title: Prince Charles Edward (Disguised as a Lady's Maid to Flora McDonald)
